an10.60:1.1.pli: Ekaṃ samayaṃ bhagavā sāvatthiyaṃ viharati jetavane anāthapiṇḍikassa ārāme.
an10.60:1.1.eng: At one time the Buddha was staying near Sāvatthī in Jeta’s Grove, Anāthapiṇḍika’s monastery.

an10.60:1.2.pli: Tena kho pana samayena āyasmā girimānando ābādhiko hoti dukkhito bāḷhagilāno.
an10.60:1.2.eng: Now at that time Venerable Girimānanda was sick, suffering, gravely ill.

an10.60:1.3.pli: Atha kho āyasmā ānando yena bhagavā tenupasaṅkami; upasaṅkamitvā bhagavantaṃ abhivādetvā ekamantaṃ nisīdi. Ekamantaṃ nisinno kho āyasmā ānando bhagavantaṃ etadavoca:
an10.60:1.3.eng: Then Venerable Ānanda went up to the Buddha, bowed, sat down to one side, and said to him:

an10.60:2.1.pli: “Āyasmā, bhante, girimānando ābādhiko hoti dukkhito bāḷhagilāno.
an10.60:2.1.eng: “Sir, Venerable Girimānanda is sick, suffering, gravely ill.

an10.60:2.2.pli: Sādhu, bhante, bhagavā yenāyasmā girimānando tenupasaṅkamatu anukampaṃ upādāyā”ti.
an10.60:2.2.eng: Sir, please go to Venerable Girimānanda out of sympathy.”

an10.60:2.3.pli: “Sace kho tvaṃ, ānanda, girimānandassa bhikkhuno dasa saññā bhāseyyāsi, ṭhānaṃ kho panetaṃ vijjati yaṃ girimānandassa bhikkhuno dasa saññā sutvā so ābādho ṭhānaso paṭippassambheyya.
an10.60:2.3.eng: “Ānanda, if you were to recite to the mendicant Girimānanda these ten perceptions, it’s possible that after hearing them his illness will die down on the spot.

an10.60:3.2.pli: Aniccasaññā, anattasaññā, asubhasaññā, ādīnavasaññā, pahānasaññā, virāgasaññā, nirodhasaññā, sabbaloke anabhiratasaññā, sabbasaṅkhāresu anicchāsaññā, ānāpānassati.
an10.60:3.2.eng: The perceptions of impermanence, not-self, ugliness, drawbacks, giving up, fading away, cessation, dissatisfaction with the whole world, impermanence of all conditions, and mindfulness of breathing.

an10.60:4.1.eng: And what is the perception of impermanence?

an10.60:4.2.pli: Idhānanda, bhikkhu araññagato vā rukkhamūlagato vā suññāgāragato vā iti paṭisañcikkhati:
an10.60:4.2.eng: It’s when a mendicant has gone to a wilderness, or to the root of a tree, or to an empty hut, and reflects like this:

an10.60:4.3.pli: ‘rūpaṃ aniccaṃ, vedanā aniccā, saññā aniccā, saṅkhārā aniccā, viññāṇaṃ aniccan’ti.
an10.60:4.3.eng: ‘Form, feeling, perception, choices, and consciousness are impermanent.’

an10.60:4.4.pli: Iti imesu pañcasu upādānakkhandhesu aniccānupassī viharati.
an10.60:4.4.eng: And so they meditate observing impermanence in the five grasping aggregates.

an10.60:4.5.eng: This is called the perception of impermanence.

an10.60:5.1.eng: And what is the perception of not-self?

an10.60:5.2.pli: Idhānanda, bhikkhu araññagato vā rukkhamūlagato vā suññāgāragato vā iti paṭisañcikkhati:
an10.60:5.2.eng: It’s when a mendicant has gone to a wilderness, or to the root of a tree, or to an empty hut, and reflects like this:

an10.60:5.3.pli: ‘cakkhu anattā, rūpā anattā, sotaṃ anattā, saddā anattā, ghānaṃ anattā, gandhā anattā, jivhā anattā, rasā anattā, kāyā anattā, phoṭṭhabbā anattā, mano anattā, dhammā anattā’ti.
an10.60:5.3.eng: ‘The eye and sights, ear and sounds, nose and smells, tongue and tastes, body and touches, and mind and ideas are not-self.’

an10.60:5.4.pli: Iti imesu chasu ajjhattikabāhiresu āyatanesu anattānupassī viharati.
an10.60:5.4.eng: And so they meditate observing not-self in the six interior and exterior sense fields.

an10.60:5.5.eng: This is called the perception of not-self.

an10.60:6.1.eng: And what is the perception of ugliness?

an10.60:6.2.pli: Idhānanda, bhikkhu imameva kāyaṃ uddhaṃ pādatalā adho kesamatthakā tacapariyantaṃ pūraṃ nānāppakārassa asucino paccavekkhati:
an10.60:6.2.eng: It’s when a mendicant examines their own body up from the soles of the feet and down from the tips of the hairs, wrapped in skin and full of many kinds of filth.

an10.60:6.3.pli: ‘atthi imasmiṃ kāye kesā lomā nakhā dantā taco, maṃsaṃ nhāru aṭṭhi aṭṭhimiñjaṃ vakkaṃ, hadayaṃ yakanaṃ kilomakaṃ pihakaṃ papphāsaṃ, antaṃ antaguṇaṃ udariyaṃ karīsaṃ, pittaṃ semhaṃ pubbo lohitaṃ sedo medo, assu vasā kheḷo siṅghāṇikā lasikā muttan’ti.
an10.60:6.3.eng: ‘In this body there is head hair, body hair, nails, teeth, skin, flesh, sinews, bones, bone marrow, kidneys, heart, liver, diaphragm, spleen, lungs, intestines, mesentery, undigested food, feces, bile, phlegm, pus, blood, sweat, fat, tears, grease, saliva, snot, synovial fluid, urine.’

an10.60:6.4.eng: And so they meditate observing ugliness in this body.

an10.60:6.5.eng: This is called the perception of ugliness.

an10.60:7.1.eng: And what is the perception of drawbacks?

an10.60:7.2.pli: Idhānanda, bhikkhu araññagato vā rukkhamūlagato vā suññāgāragato vā iti paṭisañcikkhati:
an10.60:7.2.eng: It’s when a mendicant has gone to a wilderness, or to the root of a tree, or to an empty hut, and reflects like this:

an10.60:7.3.pli: ‘bahudukkho kho ayaṃ kāyo bahuādīnavo. Iti imasmiṃ kāye vividhā ābādhā uppajjanti, seyyathidaṃ—
an10.60:7.3.eng: ‘This body has much suffering and many drawbacks. For this body is beset with many kinds of affliction, such as the following.

an10.60:7.4.pli: cakkhurogo sotarogo ghānarogo jivhārogo kāyarogo sīsarogo kaṇṇarogo mukharogo dantarogo oṭṭharogo kāso sāso pināso ḍāho jaro kucchirogo mucchā pakkhandikā sūlā visūcikā kuṭṭhaṃ gaṇḍo kilāso soso apamāro daddu kaṇḍu kacchu nakhasā vitacchikā lohitaṃ pittaṃ madhumeho aṃsā piḷakā bhagandalā pittasamuṭṭhānā ābādhā semhasamuṭṭhānā ābādhā vātasamuṭṭhānā ābādhā sannipātikā ābādhā utupariṇāmajā ābādhā visamaparihārajā ābādhā opakkamikā ābādhā kammavipākajā ābādhā sītaṃ uṇhaṃ jighacchā pipāsā uccāro passāvo’ti.
an10.60:7.4.eng: Diseases of the eye, inner ear, nose, tongue, body, head, outer ear, mouth, teeth, and lips. Cough, asthma, catarrh, inflammation, fever, stomach ache, fainting, dysentery, gastric pain, cholera, leprosy, boils, eczema, tuberculosis, epilepsy, herpes, itch, scabs, smallpox, scabies, hemorrhage, diabetes, piles, pimples, and ulcers. Afflictions stemming from disorders of bile, phlegm, wind, or their conjunction. Afflictions caused by change in weather, by not taking care of yourself, by overexertion, or as the result of past deeds. Cold, heat, hunger, thirst, defecation, and urination.’

an10.60:7.5.eng: And so they meditate observing drawbacks in this body.

an10.60:7.6.eng: This is called the perception of drawbacks.

an10.60:8.1.eng: And what is the perception of giving up?

an10.60:8.2.pli: Idhānanda, bhikkhu uppannaṃ kāmavitakkaṃ nādhivāseti, pajahati, vinodeti, byantīkaroti, anabhāvaṃ gameti. Uppannaṃ byāpādavitakkaṃ nādhivāseti, pajahati, vinodeti, byantīkaroti, anabhāvaṃ gameti. Uppannaṃ vihiṃsāvitakkaṃ nādhivāseti, pajahati, vinodeti, byantīkaroti, anabhāvaṃ gameti. Uppannuppanne pāpake akusale dhamme nādhivāseti, pajahati, vinodeti, byantīkaroti, anabhāvaṃ gameti.
an10.60:8.2.eng: It’s when a mendicant doesn’t tolerate a sensual, malicious, or cruel thought that has arisen, and they don’t tolerate any bad, unskillful qualities that have arisen, but give them up, get rid of them, eliminate them, and obliterate them.

an10.60:8.3.eng: This is called the perception of giving up.

an10.60:9.1.eng: And what is the perception of fading away?

an10.60:9.2.pli: Idhānanda, bhikkhu araññagato vā rukkhamūlagato vā suññāgāragato vā iti paṭisañcikkhati:
an10.60:9.2.eng: It’s when a mendicant has gone to a wilderness, or to the root of a tree, or to an empty hut, and reflects like this:

an10.60:9.3.pli: ‘etaṃ santaṃ etaṃ paṇītaṃ yadidaṃ sabbasaṅkhārasamatho sabbūpadhippaṭinissaggo taṇhākkhayo virāgo nibbānan’ti.
an10.60:9.3.eng: ‘This is peaceful; this is sublime—that is, the stilling of all activities, the letting go of all attachments, the ending of craving, fading away, extinguishment.’

an10.60:9.4.eng: This is called the perception of fading away.

an10.60:10.1.eng: And what is the perception of cessation?

an10.60:10.2.pli: Idhānanda, bhikkhu araññagato vā rukkhamūlagato vā suññāgāragato vā iti paṭisañcikkhati:
an10.60:10.2.eng: It’s when a mendicant has gone to a wilderness, or to the root of a tree, or to an empty hut, and reflects like this:

an10.60:10.3.pli: ‘etaṃ santaṃ etaṃ paṇītaṃ yadidaṃ sabbasaṅkhārasamatho sabbūpadhippaṭinissaggo taṇhākkhayo nirodho nibbānan’ti.
an10.60:10.3.eng: ‘This is peaceful; this is sublime—that is, the stilling of all activities, the letting go of all attachments, the ending of craving, cessation, extinguishment.’

an10.60:10.4.eng: This is called the perception of cessation.

an10.60:11.1.eng: And what is the perception of dissatisfaction with the whole world?

an10.60:11.2.pli: Idhānanda, bhikkhu ye loke upādānā cetaso adhiṭṭhānābhinivesānusayā, te pajahanto viharati anupādiyanto.
an10.60:11.2.eng: It’s when a mendicant lives giving up and not grasping on to the attraction and grasping to the world, the mental fixation, insistence, and underlying tendencies.

an10.60:11.3.eng: This is called the perception of dissatisfaction with the whole world.

an10.60:12.1.eng: And what is the perception of the impermanence of all conditions?

an10.60:12.2.pli: Idhānanda, bhikkhu sabbasaṅkhāresu aṭṭīyati harāyati jigucchati.
an10.60:12.2.eng: It’s when a mendicant is horrified, repelled, and disgusted with all conditions.

an10.60:12.3.eng: This is called the perception of the impermanence of all conditions.

an10.60:13.1.eng: And what is mindfulness of breathing?

an10.60:13.2.pli: Idhānanda, bhikkhu araññagato vā rukkhamūlagato vā suññāgāragato vā nisīdati pallaṅkaṃ ābhujitvā ujuṃ kāyaṃ paṇidhāya parimukhaṃ satiṃ upaṭṭhapetvā.
an10.60:13.2.eng: It’s when a mendicant has gone to a wilderness, or to the root of a tree, or to an empty hut, sits down cross-legged, sets their body straight, and establishes mindfulness in their presence.

an10.60:13.3.eng: Just mindful, they breathe in. Mindful, they breathe out.

an10.60:13.4.pli: Dīghaṃ vā assasanto ‘dīghaṃ assasāmī’ti pajānāti. Dīghaṃ vā passasanto ‘dīghaṃ passasāmī’ti pajānāti.
an10.60:13.4.eng: Breathing in heavily they know: ‘I’m breathing in heavily.’ Breathing out heavily they know: ‘I’m breathing out heavily.’

an10.60:13.5.pli: Rassaṃ vā assasanto ‘rassaṃ assasāmī’ti pajānāti. Rassaṃ vā passasanto ‘rassaṃ passasāmī’ti pajānāti.
an10.60:13.5.eng: When breathing in lightly they know: ‘I’m breathing in lightly.’ Breathing out lightly they know: ‘I’m breathing out lightly.’

an10.60:13.6.eng: They practice like this: ‘I’ll breathe in experiencing the whole body.’ They practice like this: ‘I’ll breathe out experiencing the whole body.’

an10.60:13.7.pli: ‘Passambhayaṃ kāyasaṅkhāraṃ assasissāmī’ti sikkhati. ‘Passambhayaṃ kāyasaṅkhāraṃ passasissāmī’ti sikkhati.
an10.60:13.7.eng: They practice like this: ‘I’ll breathe in stilling the physical process.’ They practice like this: ‘I’ll breathe out stilling the physical process.’

an10.60:13.8.eng: They practice like this: ‘I’ll breathe in experiencing rapture.’ They practice like this: ‘I’ll breathe out experiencing rapture.’

an10.60:13.9.eng: They practice like this: ‘I’ll breathe in experiencing bliss.’ They practice like this: ‘I’ll breathe out experiencing bliss.’

an10.60:13.10.eng: They practice like this: ‘I’ll breathe in experiencing the mental process.’ They practice like this: ‘I’ll breathe out experiencing the mental process.’

an10.60:13.11.pli: ‘Passambhayaṃ cittasaṅkhāraṃ assasissāmī’ti sikkhati. ‘Passambhayaṃ cittasaṅkhāraṃ passasissāmī’ti sikkhati.
an10.60:13.11.eng: They practice like this: ‘I’ll breathe in stilling the mental process.’ They practice like this: ‘I’ll breathe out stilling the mental process.’

an10.60:13.12.eng: They practice like this: ‘I’ll breathe in experiencing the mind.’ They practice like this: ‘I’ll breathe out experiencing the mind.’

an10.60:13.13.eng: They practice like this: ‘I’ll breathe in gladdening the mind.’ They practice like this: ‘I’ll breathe out gladdening the mind.’

an10.60:13.14.eng: They practice like this: ‘I’ll breathe in immersing the mind in samādhi.’ They practice like this: ‘I’ll breathe out immersing the mind in samādhi.’

an10.60:13.15.eng: They practice like this: ‘I’ll breathe in freeing the mind.’ They practice like this: ‘I’ll breathe out freeing the mind.’

an10.60:13.16.eng: They practice like this: ‘I’ll breathe in observing impermanence.’ They practice like this: ‘I’ll breathe out observing impermanence.’

an10.60:13.17.eng: They practice like this: ‘I’ll breathe in observing fading away.’ They practice like this: ‘I’ll breathe out observing fading away.’

an10.60:13.18.eng: They practice like this: ‘I’ll breathe in observing cessation.’ They practice like this: ‘I’ll breathe out observing cessation.’

an10.60:13.19.eng: They practice like this: ‘I’ll breathe in observing letting go.’ They practice like this: ‘I’ll breathe out observing letting go.’

an10.60:13.20.eng: This is called mindfulness of breathing.

an10.60:14.1.pli: Sace kho tvaṃ, ānanda, girimānandassa bhikkhuno imā dasa saññā bhāseyyāsi, ṭhānaṃ kho panetaṃ vijjati yaṃ girimānandassa bhikkhuno imā dasa saññā sutvā so ābādho ṭhānaso paṭippassambheyyā”ti.
an10.60:14.1.eng: If you were to recite to the mendicant Girimānanda these ten perceptions, it’s possible that after hearing them his illness will die down on the spot.”

an10.60:15.1.pli: Atha kho āyasmā ānando bhagavato santike imā dasa saññā uggahetvā yenāyasmā girimānando tenupasaṅkami; upasaṅkamitvā āyasmato girimānandassa imā dasa saññā abhāsi.
an10.60:15.1.eng: Then Ānanda, having learned these ten perceptions from the Buddha himself, went to Girimānanda and recited them.

an10.60:15.2.pli: Atha kho āyasmato girimānandassa dasa saññā sutvā so ābādho ṭhānaso paṭippassambhi.
an10.60:15.2.eng: Then after Girimānanda heard these ten perceptions his illness died down on the spot.

an10.60:15.3.pli: Vuṭṭhahi cāyasmā girimānando tamhā ābādhā. Tathā pahīno ca panāyasmato girimānandassa so ābādho ahosīti.
an10.60:15.3.eng: And that’s how he recovered from that illness.

an10.61:1.1.pli: “Purimā, bhikkhave, koṭi na paññāyati avijjāya: ‘ito pubbe avijjā nāhosi, atha pacchā samabhavī’ti.
an10.61:1.1.eng: “Mendicants, it is said that no prior point of ignorance is evident, before which there was no ignorance, and afterwards it came to be.

an10.61:1.2.pli: Evañcetaṃ, bhikkhave, vuccati, atha ca pana paññāyati: ‘idappaccayā avijjā’ti.
an10.61:1.2.eng: And yet it is evident that there is a specific condition for ignorance.

an10.61:2.1.pli: Avijjampāhaṃ, bhikkhave, sāhāraṃ vadāmi, no anāhāraṃ.
an10.61:2.1.eng: I say that ignorance is fueled by something, it’s not unfueled.

an10.61:2.2.eng: And what is the fuel for ignorance?

an10.61:2.4.pli: Pañcapāhaṃ, bhikkhave, nīvaraṇe sāhāre vadāmi, no anāhāre.
an10.61:2.4.eng: I say that the five hindrances are fueled by something, they’re not unfueled.

an10.61:2.5.eng: And what is the fuel for the five hindrances?

an10.61:2.6.eng: You should say: ‘The three kinds of misconduct.’

an10.61:2.7.pli: Tīṇipāhaṃ, bhikkhave, duccaritāni sāhārāni vadāmi, no anāhārāni.
an10.61:2.7.eng: I say that the three kinds of misconduct are fueled by something, they’re not unfueled.

an10.61:2.8.eng: And what is the fuel for the three kinds of misconduct?

an10.61:2.9.eng: You should say: ‘Lack of sense restraint.’

an10.61:2.10.pli: Indriyaasaṃvarampāhaṃ, bhikkhave, sāhāraṃ vadāmi, no anāhāraṃ.
an10.61:2.10.eng: I say that lack of sense restraint is fueled by something, it’s not unfueled.

an10.61:2.11.eng: And what is the fuel for lack of sense restraint?

an10.61:2.12.eng: You should say: ‘Lack of mindfulness and situational awareness.’

an10.61:2.13.pli: Asatāsampajaññampāhaṃ, bhikkhave, sāhāraṃ vadāmi, no anāhāraṃ.
an10.61:2.13.eng: I say that lack of mindfulness and situational awareness is fueled by something, it’s not unfueled.

an10.61:2.14.eng: And what is the fuel for lack of mindfulness and situational awareness?

an10.61:2.15.eng: You should say: ‘Irrational application of mind.’

an10.61:2.16.pli: Ayonisomanasikārampāhaṃ, bhikkhave, sāhāraṃ vadāmi, no anāhāraṃ.
an10.61:2.16.eng: I say that irrational application of mind is fueled by something, it’s not unfueled.

an10.61:2.17.eng: And what is the fuel for irrational application of mind?

an10.61:2.19.pli: Assaddhiyampāhaṃ, bhikkhave, sāhāraṃ vadāmi, no anāhāraṃ.
an10.61:2.19.eng: I say that lack of faith is fueled by something, it’s not unfueled.

an10.61:2.20.eng: And what is the fuel for lack of faith?

an10.61:2.21.eng: You should say: ‘Listening to an untrue teaching.’

an10.61:2.22.pli: Asaddhammassavanampāhaṃ, bhikkhave, sāhāraṃ vadāmi, no anāhāraṃ.
an10.61:2.22.eng: I say that listening to an untrue teaching is fueled by something, it’s not unfueled.

an10.61:2.23.eng: And what is the fuel for listening to an untrue teaching?

an10.61:2.24.eng: You should say: ‘Associating with untrue persons.’

an10.61:3.1.pli: Iti kho, bhikkhave, asappurisasaṃsevo paripūro asaddhammassavanaṃ paripūreti, asaddhammassavanaṃ paripūraṃ assaddhiyaṃ paripūreti, assaddhiyaṃ paripūraṃ ayonisomanasikāraṃ paripūreti, ayonisomanasikāro paripūro asatāsampajaññaṃ paripūreti, asatāsampajaññaṃ paripūraṃ indriyaasaṃvaraṃ paripūreti, indriyaasaṃvaro paripūro tīṇi duccaritāni paripūreti, tīṇi duccaritāni paripūrāni pañca nīvaraṇe paripūrenti, pañca nīvaraṇā paripūrā avijjaṃ paripūrenti;
an10.61:3.1.eng: In this way, when the factor of associating with untrue persons is fulfilled, it fulfills the factor of listening to an untrue teaching. When the factor of listening to an untrue teaching is fulfilled, it fulfills the factor of lack of faith … irrational application of mind … lack of mindfulness and situational awareness … lack of sense restraint …the three kinds of misconduct … the five hindrances. When the five hindrances are fulfilled, they fulfill ignorance.

an10.61:3.2.pli: evametissā avijjāya āhāro hoti, evañca pāripūri.
an10.61:3.2.eng: That’s the fuel for ignorance, and that’s how it’s fulfilled.

an10.61:4.1.pli: Seyyathāpi, bhikkhave, uparipabbate thullaphusitake deve vassante (…) taṃ udakaṃ yathāninnaṃ pavattamānaṃ pabbatakandarapadarasākhā paripūreti, pabbatakandarapadarasākhā paripūrā kusobbhe paripūrenti. Kusobbhā paripūrā mahāsobbhe paripūrenti, mahāsobbhā paripūrā kunnadiyo paripūrenti, kunnadiyo paripūrā mahānadiyo paripūrenti, mahānadiyo paripūrā mahāsamuddaṃ sāgaraṃ paripūrenti;
an10.61:4.1.eng: It’s like when the heavens rain heavily on a mountain top, and the water flows downhill to fill the hollows, crevices, and creeks. As they become full, they fill up the pools. The pools fill up the lakes, the lakes fill up the streams, and the streams fill up the rivers. And as the rivers become full, they fill up the ocean.

an10.61:4.2.pli: evametassa mahāsamuddassa sāgarassa āhāro hoti, evañca pāripūri.
an10.61:4.2.eng: That’s the fuel for the ocean, and that’s how it’s filled up.

an10.61:5.1.pli: Evamevaṃ kho, bhikkhave, asappurisasaṃsevo paripūro asaddhammassavanaṃ paripūreti, asaddhammassavanaṃ paripūraṃ assaddhiyaṃ paripūreti, assaddhiyaṃ paripūraṃ ayonisomanasikāraṃ paripūreti, ayonisomanasikāro paripūro asatāsampajaññaṃ paripūreti, asatāsampajaññaṃ paripūraṃ indriyaasaṃvaraṃ paripūreti, indriyaasaṃvaro paripūro tīṇi duccaritāni paripūreti, tīṇi duccaritāni paripūrāni pañca nīvaraṇe paripūrenti, pañca nīvaraṇā paripūrā avijjaṃ paripūrenti;
an10.61:5.1.eng: In the same way, when the factor of associating with untrue persons is fulfilled, it fulfills the factor of listening to an untrue teaching. When the factor of listening to an untrue teaching is fulfilled, it fulfills the factor of lack of faith … irrational application of mind … lack of mindfulness and situational awareness … lack of sense restraint …the three kinds of misconduct … the five hindrances. When the five hindrances are fulfilled, they fulfill ignorance.

an10.61:5.2.pli: evametissā avijjāya āhāro hoti, evañca pāripūri.
an10.61:5.2.eng: That’s the fuel for ignorance, and that’s how it’s fulfilled.

an10.61:6.1.pli: Vijjāvimuttimpāhaṃ, bhikkhave, sāhāraṃ vadāmi, no anāhāraṃ.
an10.61:6.1.eng: I say that knowledge and freedom are fueled by something, they’re not unfueled.

an10.61:6.2.eng: And what is the fuel for knowledge and freedom?

an10.61:6.3.eng: You should say: ‘The seven awakening factors.’

an10.61:6.4.pli: Sattapāhaṃ, bhikkhave, bojjhaṅge sāhāre vadāmi, no anāhāre.
an10.61:6.4.eng: I say that the seven awakening factors are fueled by something, they’re not unfueled.

an10.61:6.5.eng: And what is the fuel for the seven awakening factors?

an10.61:6.6.eng: You should say: ‘The four kinds of mindfulness meditation.’

an10.61:6.7.pli: Cattāropāhaṃ, bhikkhave, satipaṭṭhāne sāhāre vadāmi, no anāhāre.
an10.61:6.7.eng: I say that the four kinds of mindfulness meditation are fueled by something, they’re not unfueled.

an10.61:6.8.eng: And what is the fuel for the four kinds of mindfulness meditation?

an10.61:6.9.eng: You should say: ‘The three kinds of good conduct.’

an10.61:6.10.pli: Tīṇipāhaṃ, bhikkhave, sucaritāni sāhārāni vadāmi, no anāhārāni.
an10.61:6.10.eng: I say that the three kinds of good conduct are fueled by something, they’re not unfueled.

an10.61:6.11.eng: And what is the fuel for the three kinds of good conduct?

an10.61:6.13.pli: Indriyasaṃvarampāhaṃ, bhikkhave, sāhāraṃ vadāmi, no anāhāraṃ.
an10.61:6.13.eng: I say that sense restraint is fueled by something, it’s not unfueled.

an10.61:6.14.eng: And what is the fuel for sense restraint?

an10.61:6.15.eng: You should say: ‘Mindfulness and situational awareness.’

an10.61:6.16.pli: Satisampajaññampāhaṃ, bhikkhave, sāhāraṃ vadāmi, no anāhāraṃ.
an10.61:6.16.eng: I say that mindfulness and situational awareness is fueled by something, it’s not unfueled.

an10.61:6.17.eng: And what is the fuel for mindfulness and situational awareness?

an10.61:6.18.eng: You should say: ‘Rational application of mind.’

an10.61:6.19.pli: Yonisomanasikārampāhaṃ, bhikkhave, sāhāraṃ vadāmi, no anāhāraṃ.
an10.61:6.19.eng: I say that rational application of mind is fueled by something, it’s not unfueled.

an10.61:6.20.eng: And what is the fuel for rational application of mind?

an10.61:6.22.pli: Saddhampāhaṃ, bhikkhave, sāhāraṃ vadāmi, no anāhāraṃ.
an10.61:6.22.eng: I say that faith is fueled by something, it’s not unfueled.

an10.61:6.23.eng: And what is the fuel for faith?

an10.61:6.24.eng: You should say: ‘Listening to the true teaching.’

an10.61:6.25.pli: Saddhammassavanampāhaṃ, bhikkhave, sāhāraṃ vadāmi, no anāhāraṃ.
an10.61:6.25.eng: I say that listening to the true teaching is fueled by something, it’s not unfueled.

an10.61:6.26.eng: And what is the fuel for listening to the true teaching?

an10.61:6.27.eng: You should say: ‘Associating with true persons.’

an10.61:7.1.pli: Iti kho, bhikkhave, sappurisasaṃsevo paripūro saddhammassavanaṃ paripūreti, saddhammassavanaṃ paripūraṃ saddhaṃ paripūreti, saddhā paripūrā yonisomanasikāraṃ paripūreti, yonisomanasikāro paripūro satisampajaññaṃ paripūreti, satisampajaññaṃ paripūraṃ indriyasaṃvaraṃ paripūreti, indriyasaṃvaro paripūro tīṇi sucaritāni paripūreti, tīṇi sucaritāni paripūrāni cattāro satipaṭṭhāne paripūrenti, cattāro satipaṭṭhānā paripūrā satta bojjhaṅge paripūrenti, satta bojjhaṅgā paripūrā vijjāvimuttiṃ paripūrenti;
an10.61:7.1.eng: In this way, when the factor of associating with true persons is fulfilled, it fulfills the factor of listening to the true teaching. When the factor of listening to the true teaching is fulfilled, it fulfills the factor of faith … rational application of mind … mindfulness and situational awareness … sense restraint …the three kinds of good conduct … the four kinds of mindfulness meditation … the seven awakening factors. When the seven awakening factors are fulfilled, they fulfill knowledge and freedom.

an10.61:7.2.pli: evametissā vijjāvimuttiyā āhāro hoti, evañca pāripūri.
an10.61:7.2.eng: That’s the fuel for knowledge and freedom, and that’s how it’s fulfilled.

an10.61:8.1.pli: Seyyathāpi, bhikkhave, uparipabbate thullaphusitake deve vassante taṃ udakaṃ yathāninnaṃ pavattamānaṃ pabbatakandarapadarasākhā paripūreti, pabbatakandarapadarasākhā paripūrā kusobbhe paripūrenti, kusobbhā paripūrā mahāsobbhe paripūrenti, mahāsobbhā paripūrā kunnadiyo paripūrenti, kunnadiyo paripūrā mahānadiyo paripūrenti, mahānadiyo paripūrā mahāsamuddaṃ sāgaraṃ paripūrenti;
an10.61:8.1.eng: It’s like when the heavens rain heavily on a mountain top, and the water flows downhill to fill the hollows, crevices, and creeks. As they become full, they fill up the pools. The pools fill up the lakes, the lakes fill up the streams, and the streams fill up the rivers. And as the rivers become full, they fill up the ocean.

an10.61:8.2.pli: evametassa mahāsamuddassa sāgarassa āhāro hoti, evañca pāripūri.
an10.61:8.2.eng: That’s the fuel for the ocean, and that’s how it’s filled up.

an10.61:9.1.pli: Evamevaṃ kho, bhikkhave, sappurisasaṃsevo paripūro saddhammassavanaṃ paripūreti, saddhammassavanaṃ paripūraṃ saddhaṃ paripūreti, saddhā paripūrā yonisomanasikāraṃ paripūreti, yonisomanasikāro paripūro satisampajaññaṃ paripūreti, satisampajaññaṃ paripūraṃ indriyasaṃvaraṃ paripūreti, indriyasaṃvaro paripūro tīṇi sucaritāni paripūreti, tīṇi sucaritāni paripūrāni cattāro satipaṭṭhāne paripūrenti, cattāro satipaṭṭhānā paripūrā satta bojjhaṅge paripūrenti, satta bojjhaṅgā paripūrā vijjāvimuttiṃ paripūrenti;
an10.61:9.1.eng: In the same way, when the factor of associating with true persons is fulfilled, it fulfills the factor of listening to the true teaching. When the factor of listening to the true teaching is fulfilled, it fulfills the factor of faith … rational application of mind … mindfulness and situational awareness … sense restraint …the three kinds of good conduct … the four kinds of mindfulness meditation … the seven awakening factors. When the seven awakening factors are fulfilled, they fulfill knowledge and freedom.

an10.61:9.2.pli: evametissā vijjāvimuttiyā āhāro hoti, evañca pāripūrī”ti.
an10.61:9.2.eng: That’s the fuel for knowledge and freedom, and that’s how it’s fulfilled.”
